questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of cough productive of yellowish sputum. He has had fever, chills, and worsening shortness of breath during this time. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. His current medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, and metoprolol. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He appears in mild distress. He has rales over the left lower lung field. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Leukocyte count is 15,000/mm3 (87% segmented neutrophils). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.44


pO2

68 mm Hg


pCO2

28 mm Hg


HCO3-

24 mEq/L


O2 saturation
91%


An x-ray of the chest shows a consolidation in the left lower lobe. Asking the patient to lie down in the left lateral decubitus position would most likely result in which of the following?

choices.text: Decreased ventilation of the left lung

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the lateral decubitus position, the dependent lung is better perfused due to the effect of gravity. Putting this patient in the left lateral decubitus position will therefore increase the perfusion of the left, diseased lung, not of the right, healthy lung.

B) INCORRECT:

The perfusion of the nonventilated, consolidated alveoli in pneumonia causes a decreased ventilation-perfusion ratio that results in hypoxemia. Placing the patient in the left decubitus position would actually worsen hypoxemia as more blood passes through the nonventilated portion of the lung and less blood passes through the right, healthy lung. Additionally, the healthy lung will be ventilated less, further contributing to a worsening of hypoxemia.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's arterial blood gas analysis shows hypocapnia, as evidenced by the pCO2 of 28 mm Hg (normal pCO2: 33–45 mm Hg). In general, the dependent lung is better ventilated and perfused than the nondependent lung. Placing this patient with left lobar pneumonia in the left lateral decubitus position will increase ventilation and perfusion of the diseased lung. As there is no CO2 and O2 exchange at the sites of alveolar consolidation, there will be more CO2 retention, resulting in an improvement of the hypocapnia (but a worsening of the hypoxia) in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Dependent portions of a healthy lung are better ventilated than the nondependent portions. This patient with pneumonia affecting the left lower lobe has consolidation on x-ray, which indicates the presence of fluid in the alveoli that prevents them from participating in ventilation. However, putting this patient in the left lateral decubitus position will still result in increased ventilation of the unaffected upper lobe of the diseased lung.

E) CORRECT:

The alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) is the difference between the partial pressure of O2 within the alveoli and that within the arterial blood. An increased A-a gradient indicates a ventilation/perfusion mismatch (V/Q mismatch) resulting in hypoxia. In pneumonia, ventilation decreases in the consolidated region of the lung due to alveolar inflammation (↓ V). In a lateral decubitus position, the dependent lung is better perfused (↑ Q) and ventilated than the nondependent regions. Placing this patient with left-sided pneumonia in the left lateral decubitus position will increase perfusion of the nonventilated alveoli, worsening the V/Q mismatch and increasing the A-a gradient.

Therefore, in patients with unilateral pneumonia with hypoxia, positioning the body with the healthy lung in the dependent position (“good lung down”) improves arterial oxygenation by increasing both its ventilation and perfusion.
questions.hint: This patient presents with clinical features of pneumonia, which impairs ventilation in the affected pulmonary tissue. The dependent regions of the lung are better perfused than the nondependent regions as gravity pulls the blood downward.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male soccer player undergoes an exercise tolerance test to measure his maximal oxygen uptake during exercise. Which of the following changes are most likely to occur during exercise?

choices.text: Increased arterial partial pressure of oxygen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary vascular resistance is equivalent to the pressure difference across the pulmonary circuit divided by the rate of blood flow (cardiac output) traveling through this circuit. Exercise increases cardiac output from the right ventricle and recruits previously unperfused pulmonary vessels. The production of vasodilatory mediators (e.g., nitric oxide) also acts to increase the cross-sectional area of the pulmonary vascular bed. Together these physiologic changes act to decrease, not increase pulmonary vascular resistance.

B) CORRECT:

Physiologic dead space consists of the anatomic dead space and the alveolar dead space. In the resting state, the majority of pulmonary blood flow goes to the base of the lungs due to gravity, and therefore alveolar dead space primarily localizes to the lung apices. During exercise, vasodilation of the pulmonary vessels in the apices occurs. Additionally, the increased right ventricular cardiac output increases pulmonary circulatory pressure, allowing the opening of apical blood vessels that were collapsed at rest. These processes increase apical lung perfusion, thereby decreasing alveolar dead space and subsequently, physiologic dead space.

C) INCORRECT:

The alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) is the difference between the partial pressure of oxygen in the alveoli and in the arteries. In healthy individuals, the A-a gradient increases, rather than decreases with exercise. This is, in part, due to increased alveolar partial pressure of oxygen (PAO2) as a result of an increased ventilatory effort.

D) INCORRECT:

In the resting state, increasing the alveolar partial pressure of oxygen (PAO2) by increasing the pressure of inhaled air (e.g., positive pressure ventilation) and/or by increasing the concentration of oxygen in inhaled air (FiO2) would increase the arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2). During exercise, PAO2 increases as a result of increased ventilatory effort but PaO2 does not increase correspondingly because the mixed oxygen venous saturation (SvO2) is also decreased due to increased oxygen consumption. In fact, neither the PaO2 nor the arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) change in healthy individuals during exercise.

E) INCORRECT:

At rest, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q ratio) is higher at the apex (∼3.0) and lower at the base. This is because the majority of pulmonary blood flow goes to the base of the lungs secondary to gravity, limiting perfusion to the lung apices. Exercise increases both the ventilation and perfusion to the apices of the lungs, but perfusion increases at a faster rate. This results in a decrease, not an increase in the apical V/Q ratio.
questions.hint: Exercise increases cardiac output and pulmonary blood flow.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with coronary artery disease comes to the emergency department because of chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 3 hours. Troponin levels are elevated and an ECG shows ST-elevations in the precordial leads. Revascularization with percutaneous coronary intervention is performed, and a stent is successfully placed in the left anterior descending artery. Two days later, he complains of worsening shortness of breath. Pulse oximetry on 3L of nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. An x-ray of the chest shows distended pulmonary veins, small horizontal lines at the lung bases, and blunting of the costophrenic angles bilaterally. Which of the following findings would be most likely on a ventilation-perfusion scan of this patient?

choices.text: Increased apical ventilation with normal perfusion bilaterally
Normal ventilation with multiple, bilateral perfusion defects
Normal perfusion with bilateral ventilation defects
Normal perfusion with decreased ventilation at the right base

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A high apical ventilation-perfusion ratio is a physiologic finding in healthy lungs under resting conditions. At baseline, the lung apices receive less perfusion due to gravity, resulting in a V/Q ratio of around 3 in those areas. In situations of high oxygen demand (e.g., physical exercise), apical perfusion can be increased. This patient, however, shows signs of pulmonary edema.

B) INCORRECT:

The pattern of normal ventilation with multiple perfusion defects can be seen in patients with pulmonary emboli. Blood clots obstruct lung arteries and subsequently cause decreased perfusion. As there is no airway obstruction, ventilation is maintained. This patient's dyspnea could indicate pulmonary embolism. However, his x-ray findings and the history of a recent myocardial infarction suggests pulmonary edema.

C) INCORRECT:

A matched ventilation-perfusion ratio bilaterally (e.g., V/Q = 1) can be seen with either decrease in both ventilation and perfusion or increase in both ventilation and perfusion. Bilateral increase in V/Q can be seen with exercise, during which there is physiologic vasodilation of the apical capillaries, resulting in increased perfusion of the apices with matched ventilation. A bilateral decrease in both ventilation and perfusion can be seen in patients with emphysema due to the destruction of both the alveoli and the capillary bed. Other possibilities include the combination of two separate conditions, of which one causes alveolar hypoventilation (e.g., opioid intoxication) and the other causes pulmonary hypoperfusion (e.g., right-sided heart failure, severe hypotension). This patient shows signs of pulmonary edema, which would present with different findings.

D) CORRECT:

Areas with normal perfusion and no ventilation (ventilation-perfusion mismatch) are seen in patients with pulmonary edema. Elevated pulmonary venous pressures (secondary to decreased left ventricular function) results in increased amounts of intra-alveolar fluid, which leads to impaired alveolar ventilation. Insufficiently oxygenated blood from parts of the lungs that are not ventilated mixes with oxygenated blood from ventilated parts of the lungs, resulting in an overall decrease in PaO2, increased A-a gradient, and systemic hypoxemia.

Other conditions that can result in ventilation-perfusion mismatch include pneumonia (impaired ventilation) and pulmonary embolism (impaired perfusion).
Image Description:

Pathologic lung conditions can alter V/Q ratios.

Decreased ventilation leads to shunt perfusion (wasted perfusion) and a low V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no ventilation left (V = 0), V/Q ratio equals zero.

Decreased perfusion leads to dead space ventilation (wasted ventilation) and a high V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no perfusion left (Q = 0), V/Q ratio equals infinity.

E) INCORRECT:

Normal perfusion with focal areas of decreased ventilation can be caused by localized inflammatory processes, such as pneumonia, bronchial obstruction, or malignancy. Patients with pneumonia have increased intra-alveolar fluid in some parts of the lungs, causing a decreased ventilation of those areas. This patient's dyspnea could be a sign of pneumonia but his x-ray findings and the history of a recent myocardial infarction suggest pulmonary edema.
questions.hint: The combination of a recent myocardial infarction, worsening dyspnea, and chest x-ray findings showing pulmonary vein congestion, Kerley B lines, and pleural effusions should raise suspicion for cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of shortness of breath. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 138/75 mm Hg. Pulmonary function testing shows decreased tidal volume and normal lung compliance. This patient's pulmonary function testing is most consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Emphysema exacerbations can manifest with decreased tidal volume and compensatory tachypnea due to a collapse of alveoli and an increased residual volume. However, emphysema is characterized by increased lung compliance, unlike this patient's normal lung compliance.

B) INCORRECT:

A tension pneumothorax typically manifests with rapid (increased respiratory rate), shallow (decreased tidal volume) breathing, which is similar to this patient's breathing pattern. However, tension pneumothorax causes decreased lung compliance due to the increased intrathoracic pressure and subsequent compression of the lungs.

C) INCORRECT:

In diabetic ketoacidosis, acidemia affects the respiratory center and causes initial hyperventilation followed by deep (increased tidal volume) breaths known as Kussmaul respirations. This is different than the breathing pattern seen in this patient who has decreased tidal volume.

D) CORRECT:

Chest wall pain due to a rib fracture results in limited chest wall expansion, which leads to a decrease in tidal volume. To compensate for the decreased tidal volume (Vt), patients develop increased respiratory rate (RR) to maintain normal minute ventilation (minute ventilation = Vt x RR). Because there is no damage to the lung parenchyma (and no underlying pulmonary disease), lung compliance is normal.

In a patient with an inability to increase the respiratory rate (e.g., due to sedation), minute ventilation would be impaired and could lead to hypoxia.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary edema can manifest with decreased tidal volume due to fluid-filled alveoli and subsequent compensatory tachypnea. However, affected patients will also have decreased lung compliance, unlike this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's tachypnea and decreased tidal volume suggest a rapid, shallow breathing pattern.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being found unconscious in a park. Serum toxicology screening is positive for a drug that increases the duration of chloride influx. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



PaO2 (mm Hg)
PaCO2 (mm Hg)
A-a gradient (mm Hg)



A
78
51
8


B
98
38
17


C
99
33
9


D
79
29
10


E
63
49
25


F
73
38
29
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Barbiturates depress the respiratory center in the medulla and thus dampen the respiratory drive (hypoventilation due to CNS depression). Hypoventilation results in hypercapnia (↑ PaCO2) due to decreased CO2 elimination and hypoxemia (↓ PaO2). The alveolar gas equation dictates that the alveolar partial pressure of oxygen (PAO2) would also be decreased due to an increase in PaCO2. Since both PAO2 and PaO2 are decreased, the A-a gradient is usually within normal limits (5–10 mm Hg). An overdose of benzodiazepines, which increase the frequency of chloride channel opening, or opiates, which close presynaptic Ca2+ channels and open postsynaptic K+ channels, could also cause central hypoventilation and similar ABG findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased A-a gradient with normal PaO2 and PaCO2 can be seen during exercise as a result of increased oxygen consumption (increased respiratory quotient). A different set of findings would be expected on arterial blood gas analysis in a patient with suspected barbiturate overdose.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal PaO2, hypocapnia (↓ PaCO2), and a normal A-a gradient reflect hyperventilation without increased O2 extraction. This might be seen in conditions with increased minute ventilation due to rapid respiratory rate (e.g., panic attack, initial stage of salicylate toxicity). A different set of findings would be expected on arterial blood gas analysis in a patient with suspected barbiturate overdose.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypoxemia (↓ PaO2), hypocapnia (↓ PaCO2), and a normal A-a gradient can be seen with low ambient oxygen pressure (e.g., at high altitude), which induces compensatory tachypnea and increased CO2 elimination. A different set of findings would be expected on arterial blood gas analysis in a patient with suspected barbiturate overdose.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypoxemia (↓ PaO2), hypercapnia (↑ PaCO2), and an increased A-a gradient indicate severe ventilation-perfusion mismatch and/or decreased gas diffusion across the alveoli. This might be seen in conditions that course with decreased alveolar-capillary membrane surface area (e.g., emphysema), thickened alveolar-capillary membranes (e.g., interstitial lung disease, pulmonary fibrosis), and pulmonary edema. A different set of findings would be expected on arterial blood gas analysis in a patient with suspected barbiturate overdose.

F) INCORRECT:

Hypoxemia (↓ PaO2), normal PaCO2, and an increased A-a gradient indicate type 1 respiratory failure, which is typically seen with a mild ventilation-perfusion mismatch. A different set of findings would be expected on arterial blood gas analysis in a patient with suspected barbiturate overdose.
questions.hint: Barbiturates are GABAA agonists that prolong the duration of chloride channel opening. Increased chloride influx hyperpolarizes postsynaptic neurons, which reduces neuronal excitability in the brain. Overdose with barbiturates can manifest with sedation and even coma.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of coughing and difficulty breathing that started shortly after his mother found him in the living room playing with his older brother's toys. He appears anxious. Respirations are 33/min and pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Physical examination shows nasal flaring and intercostal retractions. Auscultation of the lungs shows a high-pitched inspiratory wheeze and absent breath sounds on the right side. There is no improvement in his oxygen saturation after applying a non-rebreather mask with 100% FiO2. Which of the following terms best describes the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's hypoxemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperventilation can be a feature of panic attacks or a compensatory mechanism to eliminate carbon dioxide (e.g., in metabolic acidosis). However, it does not cause hypoxia as neither ventilation nor perfusion are impaired.

B) INCORRECT:

Alveolar dead space refers to alveoli that are ventilated, but not perfused e.g., in pulmonary embolism. This patient aspirated a foreign body, which does not cause blockage of pulmonary vessels. Moreover, application of oxygen therapy with 100% FiO2 would improve oxygen saturation in patients with a pulmonary embolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Limitation of O2 diffusion can be found in interstitial lung diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis). Patients with interstitial lung diseases receive 100% FiO2 as part of their treatment, whereas this patient showed no improvement. Moreover, this patient's history and the sudden onset of symptoms suggest foreign body aspiration, not a chronic disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Alveolar hypoventilation (e.g., seen in obstructive sleep apnea) leads to ventilation-perfusion mismatch. However, this mismatch can be compensated by application of 100% FiO2. Additionally, the alveolar-arterial gradient would be normal despite the ventilation-perfusion mismatch.

E) CORRECT:

This toddler aspirated a foreign body, which creates a ventilation-perfusion mismatch. Poorly oxygenated blood is transported from the right side of the heart to the left side of the heart, creating a right-to-left shunt. Failure to improve PaO2 by oxygen therapy (an increased alveolar-arterial gradient) in patients with hypoxemia is typical for a shunt, as PaO2 cannot be improved in the unventilated lung units.
Image Description:

Pathologic lung conditions can alter V/Q ratios.

Decreased ventilation leads to shunt perfusion (wasted perfusion) and a low V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no ventilation left (V = 0), V/Q ratio equals zero.

Decreased perfusion leads to dead space ventilation (wasted ventilation) and a high V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no perfusion left (Q = 0), V/Q ratio equals infinity.
questions.hint: Sudden onset of dyspnea and stridor in a previously healthy toddler should raise suspicion of foreign body aspiration. The absence of improvement with 100% FiO2 suggests an increased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to a physician for a routine health maintenance examination. One week ago, she moved to the mountains in Denver after living in New York City all her life. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely on analysis of a blood sample obtained now compared to prior to her move?



Erythropoietin level
O2 saturation
Plasma volume



A
↓
unchanged
↑


B
Unchanged
↓
unchanged


C
Unchanged
unchanged
↓


D
↑
unchanged
unchanged


E
↑
↓
↓
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of decreased EPO levels, normal oxygen saturation, and increased plasma volume can be seen in patients with primary polycythemia, a condition resulting from congenital (i.e., primary familial and congenital polycythemia) or acquired (e.g., polycythemia vera) bone marrow defects. This patient's recent move to a higher altitude makes another set of changes more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

The combination of decreased blood oxygen saturation with normal EPO levels and plasma volume can be seen in CO poisoning and any acute pulmonary process causing hypoxia (e.g., pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, pulmonary edema). This patient's recent move to a higher altitude makes another set of changes more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of reduced plasma volume with normal EPO and oxygen saturation levels can be seen in relative polycythemia, which is characterized by an increase in erythrocyte count secondary to fluid loss (e.g., due to diarrhea). This patient's recent move to a higher altitude makes another set of changes more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of increased EPO levels with normal oxygen saturation and plasma volume can be seen in physiologically inappropriate secondary polycythemia, in which autonomous production of EPO (e.g., by renal cell carcinoma) leads to an increased erythrocyte count. This patient's recent move to a higher altitude makes another set of changes more likely.

E) CORRECT:

The partial pressure of oxygen decreases as altitude increases, reducing pulmonary gas exchange. Therefore, this patient's recent move from New York to Denver likely caused decreased O2 saturation and mild hypoxemia. In response to hypoxemia, EPO levels rise, which increases hematocrit and improves the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. In addition, plasma volume falls rapidly in the first few days at high altitude due to decreased renal bicarbonate and water reabsorption compensating for respiratory alkalosis, as well as a fluid shift from the intravascular to the intracellular and interstitial space. This combination of changes is referred to as physiologically appropriate secondary polycythemia. (See “Causes of polycythemia” table.)

Over a prolonged stay at high altitude, EPO levels will stay slightly elevated, whereas plasma volume will slowly return to normal.
questions.hint: New York City is located at sea level, while Denver is known as the “mile-high city” (1,610 meters above sea level). Barometric pressure decreases with elevation, reducing the partial pressure of oxygen.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and confusion. His pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 109/73 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not time or place. A graph of his breathing pattern and oxygen saturation is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the observed breathing pattern?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Advanced heart failure can cause severe dyspnea with Cheyne-Stokes breathing as seen in this case. The underlying mechanism of Cheyne-Stokes breathing is a delay between ventilatory changes and the detection of resultant changes in PaCO2, which leads to cyclical hyperpnea and hypopnea due to inappropriate overcompensation of the perceived oxygen saturation state. This is depicted in the graph as episodic hyperpnea in response to low oxygen saturation and episodic hypopnea in response to high oxygen saturation. In addition to advanced heart failure, neurologic disorders that damage the respiratory center of the brain (e.g., stroke, traumatic brain injury) can also cause this pattern of breathing.

Several factors contribute to the delay between ventilatory changes and the detection of resultant changes in PaCO2, including prolonged circulation time between the lungs and brain (which delays the detection of oxygenation changes by central chemoreceptors) and a decreased ability of the body to store CO2 and O2.
Image Description:

Normal resting respiration: regular, automatic sequences of inspiration and expiration

Kussmaul respiration: regular but deepened breathing (occurs in acidosis)

Biot respiration (cluster respiration): groups (clusters) of irregular breaths followed by periods of apnea (occurs if the respiratory center in the medulla oblongata is damaged)

Cheyne-Stokes respiration: spindle-like, periodic increase and decrease in the depth of respiration; interrupted by short phases of apnea (occurs if the respiratory center in the medulla oblongata is damaged)

Agonal respiration: single, deep breaths with long pauses in between (occurs in cardiac arrest)

B) INCORRECT:

A rib fracture is likely to cause pain with deep breathing. As a result, patients often have rapid, shallow breathing with low tidal volumes, unlike the breathing pattern observed in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Opioid use can cause Biot respirations. This pathologic breathing pattern is characterized by irregular frequency of breathing, irregular tidal volumes, and apneic episodes, unlike the breathing pattern observed in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Late stages of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) manifest with severe dyspnea as seen in this case. However, advanced COPD is associated with rapid, shallow breathing, unlike the breathing pattern observed in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Metabolic acidoses can manifest with Kussmaul respirations, which are deep, regular breaths with a normal or altered rate, unlike the breathing pattern observed in this case.
questions.hint: The graph of the respiratory amplitude shows a spindle-like curve, which indicates periodic increase and decrease in the depth of respiration, interrupted by short phases of apnea. This pattern is consistent with Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

questions.text: A 21-year-old lacrosse player comes to the doctor for an annual health assessment. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 57 kg (125 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Pulmonary function tests show an FEV1 of 90% and an FVC of 3600 mL. Whole body plethysmography is performed to measure airway resistance. Which of the following structures of the respiratory tree is likely to have the highest contribution to total airway resistance?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Respiratory bronchioles have a small diameter, but due to their high number and large cross-sectional area, they are not the greatest contributors to total airway resistance.

B) INCORRECT:

The two mainstem bronchi, which branch directly from the trachea, contribute significantly to the total airway resistance. However, because of their wide diameter, they are not the greatest contributors.

C) INCORRECT:

Because of its wide diameter, the trachea is not the most significant contributor to total airway resistance.

D) CORRECT:

Intermediate-size bronchi, especially the segmental bronchi, are the greatest contributors to total airway resistance because of their low total cross-sectional area. Although airway resistance in a single large airway is lower than in a single small airway, the increased total cross-sectional area of the large number of parallel pathways dramatically decreases total airway resistance. Moreover, airflow becomes laminar in small airways, which further decreases airway resistance. This explains why small airways (< 2 mm in diameter) account for less than 20% of total airway resistance.
Image Description:

The trachea divides into two main bronchi that further divide into the lobar bronchi. The lobar bronchi then split into to the segmental bronchi that divide into the subsegmental bronchi. The walls of these sections consist of three layers: the respiratory epithelium, the cartilage plates, and the submucosa.
In the following sections of the respiratory tree, the cartilage plates are replaced by a strong layer of smooth muscle. The absence of cartilage defines the bronchioles. The terminal bronchioles branch into respiratory bronchioles, which eventually end in alveoli.

E) INCORRECT:

Conducting bronchioles contribute to the total airway resistance but due to their high number and large cross-sectional area, they are not the greatest contributors.

F) INCORRECT:

Alveolar ducts have the narrowest diameter in the respiratory tree and therefore the highest resistance per unit length. However, due to their extremely high number and large total cross-sectional area, they are not the greatest contributors to total airway resistance.

G) INCORRECT:

They have a small diameter but because of their high number and large cross-sectional area, the terminal bronchioles are usually the region of the respiratory tree that contributes the least to total airway resistance.
questions.hint: The type of flow (laminar flow has a low resistance; turbulent flow has a high resistance), diameter of the airway (as the diameter of the airway decreases, resistance increases), and the number of parallel pathways (as the total cross-sectional area decreases, resistance increases) all affect total airway resistance.

questions.text:
An investigator is studying cardiovascular changes in athletes during exercise. Participants run on a treadmill at low, moderate, and high intensity in 5-minute intervals. After each interval, an echocardiogram is performed and blood samples are collected. Which of the following sets of findings would be present in an athlete following a moderate intensity interval?



Cardiac output
PaO2

PaCO2

Venous blood pH



A
Decreased
normal
normal
normal


B
Increased
normal
normal
decreased


C
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


D
Normal
normal
decreased
increased


E
Increased
decreased
decreased
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased cardiac output with normal PaO2, PaCO2, and venous blood pH can be seen in the case of systolic dysfunction without pulmonary edema but not in an exercising individual.

B) CORRECT:

In exercising individuals, cardiac output increases due to an elevated stroke volume and heart rate. The depth and rate of respiration also increase, but PaCO2 and PaO2 remain normal because the increase in oxygenation and CO2 washout is offset by higher O2 consumption and CO2 production in the exercising muscles. Therefore, the venous blood of exercising patients will have low O2 tension and high CO2 tension. The pH of the venous blood also decreases as a result of the high CO2 tension and lactic acid production.

C) INCORRECT:

A decrease in cardiac output, PaO2, PaCO2, and venous blood pH is characteristic of massive pulmonary embolism. In affected patients, the large pulmonary embolus obstructs pulmonary blood flow and thereby decreases cardiac output. Hyperventilation caused by the hypoxic ventilatory drive results in increased CO2 washout. Finally, the pH of venous blood decreases as a result of lactic acidosis induced by poor tissue perfusion. A different set of findings would be expected in an exercising individual.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased PaCO2 and increased venous blood pH with normal cardiac output and PaO2 can be seen in cases of voluntary hyperventilation in resting individuals but not in an exercising individual.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased cardiac output with decreased PaO2, decreased PaCO2, and increased venous blood pH can be seen in patients with altitude sickness. In such patients, hyperventilation caused by the hypoxic ventilatory drive results in increased CO2 washout and respiratory alkalosis. Stimulation of pacemaker cells and carotid chemoreceptors by hypoxemia increases the heart rate and thereby increases cardiac output. A different set of findings would be expected in an exercising individual.
questions.hint: During exercise, the body experiences physiological changes as its demands for energy and oxygen increase.

questions.text: A healthy 21-year-old man undergoes physical fitness testing prior to long-term submarine deployment. To evaluate his pulmonary function, lung and thoracic compliance are measured at different system pressures. A graph of the relationship between his lung volume and transpulmonary pressure is shown. The dotted line in this graph corresponds to which of the following lung volumes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inspiratory capacity is the maximum volume of gas that can be inhaled after a normal expiration (i.e., the difference between total lung capacity and the volume of gas that remains in the lungs at the end of a normal expiration). Total lung capacity is represented by the lung volume at maximum transpulmonary pressure of the combined lung-thorax system. Thus, inspiratory capacity on the graph is the vertical distance between this lung volume and the dotted line.

B) INCORRECT:

Vital capacity is the largest volume of gas that can be exhaled after a maximal inspiration (i.e., the difference between total lung capacity and residual volume). Total lung capacity is represented by the lung volume at maximum transpulmonary pressure of the combined lung-thorax system. Residual volume is represented by the lung volume at minimum transpulmonary pressure of the combined lung-thorax system. Thus, vital capacity on the graph is the vertical distance between the highest and lowest points of the combined lung-thorax system curve.

C) INCORRECT:

Tidal volume is the volume of gas inhaled into the lungs during a normal resting breath. The dotted line is the volume of gas that remains in the lungs at the end of a normal expiration. Thus, tidal volume on the graph is represented by the vertical distance between lung volume after a normal inhalation and the dotted line.

D) CORRECT:

After a normal expiration, the combined transpulmonary pressure of the lungs and thorax is zero (i.e., atmospheric pressure) because the tendency of the lung to collapse inward (due to positive transpulmonary pressure) is equal in magnitude to the tendency of the thorax to move outward (due to negative transpulmonary pressure). Thus, the lung volume at the point where the combined lung-thorax system exerts no transpulmonary pressure (i.e., 0 cm H2O) is the functional residual capacity (i.e., the volume of gas that remains in the lungs after a normal expiration).
Image Description:

The combination of the resting tension curve of the lung (blue line) and the thorax (orange line) form the resting tension curve of the entire respiratory tract (purple line). The pressure-volume relationship apply to passive changes in the lung volume with relaxed respiratory muscles

All of the curves run in an S-like shape. However, in normal respiration, the shape is only noticeable in the curve of the entire respiratory tract (purple). In each of the curves, the compliance is highest at the steepest part of the curve (advantageous for resting breathing).
At the upper white dot, where the resting tension curve of the thorax passes by 0 in pressure, the thorax is in resting position. At the lower white dot, where the resting tension curve of the respiratory tract passes by 0 in pressure, the elastic forces of the thorax and of the lung are balanced (respiratory rest position).

With maximum expiration, the resting tension curve of the lung reaches 0 in pressure. Negative qualities would only occur with a collapse of the alveoli.

TV=tidal volume; FRC=functional residual capacity; VC=vital capacity; RV=residual volume

E) INCORRECT:

Total lung capacity is the largest volume of gas that can be held in the lungs after a maximal inspiration, which is the lung volume at maximum transpulmonary pressure of the combined lung-thorax system.
questions.hint: The dotted line represents the lung volume at the point of neutral pressure (0 cm H2O) for the combined lung-thorax system, which occurs at the end of a normal expiration.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath, exercise intolerance, and cough for the past 6 months. He is no longer able to climb a full flight of stairs without resting and uses 3 pillows to sleep at night. He has a history of using cocaine in his early 30s but has not used any illicit drugs for the past 20 years. His pulse is 99/min, respiratory rate is 21/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral fluffy infiltrates and thickening of the interlobar fissures, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Which of the following findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased pulmonary vascular resistance would not be expected in a patient with congestive heart failure. CHF is characterized by reduced cardiac output that results in a backup of blood in the pulmonary vasculature. The ensuing pulmonary venous congestion causes an increase in pulmonary vascular resistance.

B) CORRECT:

Poor left ventricular function impairs the forward flow of blood and subsequently results in excess blood within the pulmonary vasculature. This excess of blood leads to vascular engorgement, extravasation due to increased hydrostatic pressure, and pulmonary edema. Increased fluid within the lungs makes the lungs stiffer, reducing lung compliance.

C) INCORRECT:

Forced expiratory volume (FEV) is most commonly reduced by obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, COPD), which can present with dyspnea, exercise intolerance, cough, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette (due to right ventricular hypertrophy). However, auscultation would reveal bilateral wheezes and a chest x-ray would show features of pulmonary hyperinflation (e.g., increased radiolucency, flattening of the diaphragm). Crackles and fluffy infiltrates would not be expected. This patient's presentation is more consistent with CHF, which would not significantly affect FEV.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased carbon dioxide production is one of the causes of hypercapnia and may be due to physiologic states (e.g., exercise) or pathologic conditions (e.g., sepsis). This patient's presentation is consistent with CHF, which would be unlikely to cause an increase in carbon dioxide production.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased residual volume (RV) due to air trapping is seen in obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, COPD), which can present with dyspnea, exercise intolerance, cough, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette (due to right ventricular hypertrophy). However, auscultation would reveal bilateral wheezes and a chest x-ray would show features of pulmonary hyperinflation (e.g., increased radiolucency, flattening of the diaphragm). Crackles and fluffy infiltrates would not be expected. This patient's presentation is more consistent with CHF, which would be associated with a normal or reduced residual volume as a result of cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
questions.hint: This patient's history of reduced exercise tolerance and orthopnea, physical examination showing crackles and hypotension, and imaging showing cardiomegaly and pulmonary edema are highly suggestive of congestive heart failure (CHF) due to left ventricular dysfunction.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit for respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. His minute ventilation is calculated to be 7.0 L/min, and his alveolar ventilation is calculated to be 5.1 L/min. Which of the following is most likely to decrease the difference between minute ventilation and alveolar ventilation?

choices.text: Increasing the partial pressure of inhaled oxygen
Decreasing the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing the respiratory rate increases both minute ventilation and alveolar ventilation. However, the magnitude of the increase in minute ventilation is greater than that of alveolar ventilation because an increased respiratory rate also increases alveolar dead space ventilation. Therefore, increasing the respiratory rate increases, not decreases, the difference between minute ventilation and alveolar ventilation.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing the partial pressure of inhaled oxygen improves oxygenation of the blood because it increases the alveolar partial pressure of oxygen. Because gas moves from areas of high partial pressure to areas of low partial pressure, a greater pressure difference creates a strong gradient for oxygen to diffuse across the blood-air barrier into the blood. The partial pressure of inhaled oxygen does not affect ventilation or volume parameters.

C) CORRECT:

The physiologic dead space consists of the volume of air in the conducting airways (i.e., anatomic dead space) and the sum of the volumes of alveoli that do not participate in gas exchange (i.e., alveolar dead space). Decreasing the physiologic dead space reduces the difference between minute ventilation (tidal volume x respiratory rate) and alveolar ventilation ([tidal volume – physiologic dead space volume] x respiratory rate).

In healthy lungs, physiologic dead space is approximately equivalent to anatomic dead space. In diseases that result in decreased perfusion of lung tissue (e.g., pulmonary embolism), there is increased alveolar dead space ventilation.
Image Description:

The physiologic dead space (VD) consists of the volume of air in the conducting airways (i.e., anatomic dead space) and the sum of alveolar volumes that do not participate in gas exchange (i.e., alveolar dead space). In a healthy lung, anatomical dead space is almost equal to VD because alveolar dead space is negligible. In diseases that result in a mismatch in lung ventilation/perfusion ratio (e.g., pulmonary embolism), alveolar dead space is increased, resulting in reduced alveolar ventilation (the volume of gas that reaches the alveoli each minute).

D) INCORRECT:

Decreasing the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen (i.e., a right-shift of the oxygen dissociation curve for hemoglobin) facilitates the unloading of oxygen in the peripheral tissues and leads to better tissue oxygenation. It does not affect ventilation or volume parameters.

E) INCORRECT:

Increasing the respiratory depth per breath (i.e., tidal volume) increases minute ventilation and alveolar ventilation in the same proportion and, therefore, does not change the difference between these two values.
questions.hint: Minute ventilation is the volume of air that a person breathes per minute. Alveolar ventilation is the volume of air that reaches the alveoli per minute.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department with difficulty breathing. His oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. Arterial blood gas shows PaO2 55 mm Hg. The calculated alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient is 14 mm Hg (normal for age). Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for his presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism causes ventilation-perfusion mismatch due to areas of ventilation without adequate perfusion. This condition results in an increased A-a gradient, which is inconsistent with the normal gradient seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia causes fluid accumulation in alveoli and lung consolidation. This pulmonary pathology typically manifests with an increased A-a gradient due to ventilation-perfusion mismatch and intrapulmonary shunting, not the normal gradient observed here.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute respiratory distress syndrome involves widespread alveolar damage with fluid accumulation and impaired oxygenation. This severe pulmonary condition causes a significantly increased A-a gradient due to shunting, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, and impaired gas exchange across the alveolar-capillary membrane, which does not match the normal gradient in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Myasthenia gravis causes respiratory muscle weakness leading to alveolar hypoventilation. The weakened respiratory muscles cannot maintain adequate ventilation, resulting in decreased alveolar oxygen levels without impairment of gas exchange across the alveolar-capillary membrane. This neuromuscular disorder produces hypoxemia with a normal A-a gradient because there is no defect in pulmonary gas diffusion, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, or shunt.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary edema results in fluid accumulation in alveoli and impaired gas exchange across the alveolar-capillary membrane. This pulmonary pathology typically manifests with an increased A-a gradient due to ventilation-perfusion mismatch and decreased diffusion capacity, not the normal gradient observed here.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with sudden onset dyspnea and substernal chest pain. She has a history of recent immobilization following orthopedic surgery. Vital signs are BP, 138/82; P, 105; R, 24; oxygen saturation, 89% on room air. Arterial blood gas analysis shows pH 7.46, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, and PaO2 55 mm Hg. The patient appears anxious and has mild tachycardia. What is the most likely mechanism of hypoxemia in this patient?

choices.text: Impaired diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane
Ventilation-perfusion mismatch with increased dead space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired diffusion occurs when the alveolar-capillary membrane is thickened or the surface area is reduced (e.g., in interstitial lung disease or pulmonary fibrosis). Impaired diffusion causes an elevated alveolar-arterial gradient but typically manifests with chronic progressive dyspnea rather than acute onset symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased inspired oxygen concentration occurs at high altitude due to decreased barometric pressure. This mechanism causes hypoxemia but maintains a normal alveolar-arterial gradient because there is no defect in gas exchange across the alveolar-capillary membrane. The clinical context does not suggest altitude exposure.

C) INCORRECT:

Alveolar hypoventilation from CNS depression, opioid use, or respiratory muscle weakness causes hypoxemia with hypercapnia and a normal alveolar-arterial gradient. The patient's low PaCO2 of 30 mm Hg suggests hyperventilation rather than hypoventilation.

D) INCORRECT:

Right-to-left intracardiac shunting can cause hypoxemia with an elevated alveolar-arterial gradient. However, intracardiac shunting typically manifests with cyanosis from birth or is associated with congenital heart disease rather than acute onset dyspnea.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation of sudden dyspnea with recent immobilization suggests pulmonary embolism, which causes ventilation-perfusion mismatch with increased physiological dead space. Blood flow obstruction creates areas of ventilation without perfusion (increased V/Q ratio), resulting in an elevated alveolar-arterial gradient and hypoxemia.
